text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

CCDM 30.7.4.2.1.1 was revised to emphasize that all three components of a suggestion must be present, add examples of suggestions that would be excluded from consideration because they call attention to routine maintenance or repair work, and clarify that proposals pertaining to other agencies are outside the IRS’ mission.
ON OTHER DOCUMENTS CCDM 30.7.4, dated May 01, 2013, is superseded.
Table of
Special Topics
) This section covers a range of subjects, including the Employee Suggestion Program. (
) The Employee Suggestion Program provides employees with the opportunity submit constructive proposals that identify and describe a specific need for provement, and propose a solution. (
) The suggestion must directly contribute to the economy, efficiency or ness of government operations. (
) An employee who submits a suggestion will receive a prompt, objective and fair evaluation of the proposal, and may receive an award if the suggestion adopted. (

) The Office of Chief Counsel participates in the Employee Suggestion (ESP) overseen by the IRS Human Capital Office. Employees submit tions through an online system that is available at Employee Suggestion Program homepage. a. If an employee does not have access to the ESP system, he/she may submit a suggestion by completing and signing Form
, I Suggest . . .. b. If an employee submits a suggestion by using Form
, the signed form must be given to an Administrative Officer or Finance and ment (F&M) Office Manager, who will input the information into the ESP system. Where possible, the Form
from the employee should be electronically scanned and loaded into the ESP system as an (

) Various user guides and handbooks are available on the ESP website for sistance in developing suggestions and submitting them through the online system. Prior to submitting a suggestion, employees are encouraged to the ESP system for similar suggestions via the “Search” screen. (
) Chief Counsel employees are not limited to submitting suggestions related Chief Counsel operations. Suggestions may address any procedures or systems within IRS. (
) Two or more employees may jointly submit a suggestion; any award granted would be shared equally. (
) In order to be considered an acceptable suggestion, the suggestion must be constructive, i.e., it must contribute to the economy, efficiency or of Chief Counsel or IRS operations. (
) The suggestion must include the following three elements:
A statement of the problem or a description of the current situation,
The proposed solution to the problem, and
An explanation of the possible benefits of the suggestion Caution: Suggestions that are not constructive or do not contain these three elements will not be considered for adoption.

ation under the Employee Suggestion Program: (cid:
) Duplicates of a suggestion already under consideration, or one that was considered within the preceding two years (cid:
) Suggestions where the potential benefit(s) would not offset the cost of implementation (cid:
) Suggestions to correct typographical errors in printed or published (cid:
) Suggestions that call attention to routine maintenance or repair work, software fixes and upgrades that a part of the normal course of business (cid:
) Suggestions to improve working conditions, e.g., air conditioning, decora- tions, furniture (cid:
) Suggestions for routine or normal safety practices (cid:
) Suggestions for employee services and benefits, e.g., vending machines, cafeteria services, parking facilities, holidays (cid:
) Complaints, grievances or other proposals that do not include a specific means for improving operations in the Office of Chief Counsel or the Service (cid:
) Suggestions that are clearly within the employee’s job responsibilities, unless they are so superior and/or meritorious that they warrant special consideration (cid:
) Proposals that are outside the IRS’ mission, e.g., suggestions pertaining operations in other Federal agencies or bureaus (

) Statement of the Problem. The suggestion must contain specific details tifying the item, procedure or program that is the subject of the proposal; the problem that results from the current situation; and the impact the problem on IRS/Chief Counsel operations, employees or the public. (

) Proposed Solution. The suggestion must fully describe how the suggestion would address the problem, where the suggestion would be used, what dures or internal directives would need to be changed, etc. (
) Possible Benefits. The suggestion must describe the benefits that would result from implementation of the change, including either or both of the following types: (cid:
) Tangible Benefits — Improvements that can be identified entirely in terms of a dollar amount, e.g., labor, travel, training, supplies (cid:
) Intangible Benefits — Improvements that cannot be expressed solely in monetary terms, e.g., quality, morale, decreased employee turnover, reduction of taxpayer burden (

) Although the submitting employee is not required to prepare a cost benefit analysis, suggestions should include sufficient information for such an to be completed during the review. Example: – Time currently being used versus time potentially saved – The grades and number of employees affected – Volumes involved – Frequency of work performed – Expenditures required for implementation, such as training,

30.7.4.2.1.2 (05-01-2013) Components of the Suggestion
(cid:
) Tangible Benefits — Improvements that can be identified entirely in terms of a dollar amount, e.g., labor, travel, training, supplies (cid:
) Intangible Benefits — Improvements that cannot be expressed solely in monetary terms, e.g., quality, morale, decreased employee turnover, reduction of taxpayer burden

– Time currently being used versus time potentially saved – The grades and number of employees affected – Volumes involved – Frequency of work performed – Expenditures required for implementation, such as training, etc.

The required fields in the “I Suggest” screen on the ESP system must be completed. Additional information that supports the suggestion can be by following the “ add attachments” instructions. The ESP system is not a secure system and should not contain data, nor disclose information subject to the Privacy Act. Some of the fields in the “I Suggest” screen will be automatically completed when the employee accesses the system. Changes to this employee tion can be made via the “ Edit Profile” screen. If employees who have submitted suggestions leave the Office of Chief Counsel or the IRS before the evaluation process is completed, they provide the ESP Program Manager with a forwarding address. The Office of Chief Counsel’s ESP Program Manager in the Planning and Finance Division (CC:FM:PM) will review submitted suggestions for ness and adherence to the criteria in CCDM
a. Incomplete suggestions will be returned to the submitter for additional formation. If the suggestions are not completed and returned to the Program Manager within
days the suggestion will be closed. b. Suggestions that do not meet the ESP criteria will be declined. Suggestions under consideration may be evaluated by one or more of the following: (cid:
) Chief Counsel and IRS ESP Program Managers (cid:
) ESP Suggestion Coordinators in Chief Counsel and IRS (cid:
) Subject matter experts in applicable program area(s) Suggestions are identified by the number assigned in the ESP system; submitted by Chief Counsel employees begin with “

”. The identification number also contains a fiscal year code. The process of evaluation consists of: a. Identifying and analyzing the costs, benefits, advantages and disadvan- tages of a suggestion b. Determining whether a suggestion’s implementation is feasible, ing time, resources, policy, regulations, and law c. Recommending whether a suggestion should be implemented (“ d. Determining whether an award should be recommended The resources located on the ESP website under the “Evaluators” tab, including requisite suggestion processing timeframes, should be used in the evaluation process. The results of the analysis and review will be documented on Form
, gestion Evaluation. The form can be accessed through either the ESP or the IRS Forms Catalog. The evaluator will upload both the Form

supporting documentation to the ESP system. After the final review, suggestions will be forwarded to the appropriate Approving Official with a draft decision letter. (Templates for decision letters available on the ESP website.) “Approving Officials” are managers with the authority to decide whether the suggestion will be implemented/adopted in whole or in part, and, if implemented, whether an award will be given. Caution: The ESP system is not a secure system and should not contain data, nor disclose information subject to the Privacy Act.

If employees who have submitted suggestions leave the Office of Chief Counsel or the IRS before the evaluation process is completed, they should provide the ESP Program Manager with a forwarding address.

After the final review, suggestions will be forwarded to the appropriate Approving Official with a draft decision letter. (Templates for decision letters are available on the ESP website.) “Approving Officials” are managers with the authority to decide whether the suggestion will be implemented/adopted in whole or in part, and, if implemented, whether an award will be given.
Management (

) A decision letter signed by the Approving Official will be sent to the (or employees in the case of a group suggestion) stating whether the tion will be adopted. A copy of the letter will be uploaded to the ESP and the suggestion will be closed. (

) If the Approving Official is in the Office of Chief Counsel, the suggestion evaluator will prepare a cover memorandum recommending adoption, and by summarizing the principal benefits and costs described on the Form
package will contain all of the following: (cid:
) Description of actions necessary for implementation, e.g., changes to processes, procedural guidance, system modifications, purchases (cid:
) The completed Form
(cid:
) A draft decision letter (cid:
) A completed Form
, Recommendation for Recognition (

) Due to the nature of the suggestion, implementation may require the rence of several organizations. In this case the Approving Official with the primary program interest will be responsible for obtaining the required to implement the suggestion. (

) After the Approving Official makes the decision to implement the whole or in part, or to disapprove its implementation, the complete package be forwarded to Chief Counsel’s ESP Program Manager (CC:FM:PM). (
) Approved Forms
will be forwarded by the ESP Program Manager to IRS Human Capital Office for funds certification. All suggestion awards are paid from the fund maintained by the ESP Servicewide Program Office. (
) The Approving Official will take the necessary action(s) to implement the gestion. (
) An incomplete suggestion that has been returned to an employee may be submitted within
days with the necessary information added. of (

) After a suggestion has been evaluated and the decision was made to adopt or not adopt the suggestion, a request for reconsideration must be submitted within two years of the date of the final decision letter. A request reconsideration may be submitted by employees or their manager if: (cid:
) They have information showing that the suggestion was not properly evaluated (cid:
) They can provide new data or facts that would materially affect the tion decision (cid:

) They can show that an award amount, if paid, was not properly derived, i.e., they want the estimated tangible savings used to calculate the amount re-evaluated to determine if the actual savings exceed the projected amount (

) Chief Counsel employees should submit their request for reconsideration through the online system. If an employee can not access the ESP system, written request for reconsideration may be given to an Administrative F&M Office Manager, who will submit the request via the ESP system. The ESP Program Manager will forward requests that meet the criteria above to appropriate Chief Counsel or IRS organization for reconsideration. Chief Counsel Directives Manual Cat. No.
